document.text: William L. Stanley , William Leroy Stanley, 50, of Amherst Turnpike, Madison Heights, died at 1125 p.m. ,  Sunday in Lynchburg General y Hospital after a short illness.  His wife is June Wooldridge Flowers Stanley. Born in Appomattox, he was a son of the late William Henry Stanley and M ary Guill Stanley. He was an employee of Sprouses Trucking Co., a Navy veteran of World War H, and a member of Temple Baptist Church. In addition to his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Barbara S. Doss of Madison Heights, a stepson. Tommy Flowers, Jr. of Greensboro, N. C. five stepdaughters, Rebecca Flowers of Lynchburg, Mrs. Larry Cash of Madison Heights, Mrs. Steve Brown and Mrs. David Phiffer, both of Greens- , boro, and Mrs. William Jessup of Richmond five brothers, Aubrey E. Stanley, George T. Stanley, both of Madison H eights and Melvin H. Stanley, James T. Stanley and James David Stanley, all of Lynchburg three sisters, Mrs. Rachel Williams,. Mrs. Nellie M cFadden and M rs. Lula Frances Smith, all of Lynch burg and nine grandchildren. Funeral services were con ducted at 3 p.m. Wednesday from Whitten Park Avenue Chapel by the Rev. David Ralston. Burial was in Spring Hill Cemetery.

T am 59 years old and under State Police regulations could have worked until January 1, 19- 64, but chose to retire early to run for sheriff of our county. document.text: The Red Oak Baptist Church in Oakville will have revival services beginning this Friday evening at 730 p.m. Services will also be held Saturday evening at 730 p.m. and Sunday at 1055 a.m. and 730 p.m- The Rev. Daniel L. Stanley, student at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary in Wake Forest, N.C. and a native of Roanoke, will be preaching. Rev. Stanley, an experienced preacher, served for two years aa u Missionary Journeyman to Ghana, WestAfrica, _ Journeyman to Ghana, West Africa. The public is cordially invited to attend these services and to join with the church in a covered dish dinner on Sunday at 600 p.m. The Rev. James R. Vaught is pastor.

document.text: The marriage of Miss Patricia Burton Durham to Alton Eugene Lucado, Jr. took place Saturday, July 1, 1978 in Rivermont Avenue Baptist Church at 4 oclock. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Jean L.Durham and Arthur B. Durham, both of Lynchburg. The bridegroom is the son of Alton E. Lucado, Sr. and Mrs. Jean F. Brown, all of Appomattox. The Rev. Lenn Lloyd, pastor of Leewood Baptist Church, officiated at the double ring ceremony. The bride was escorted and given in marriage by her father. Mrs. Charlotte B. Page, of Pamplin was matron of honor, and attendants were Ms. Audrey D. Lee, of Lynchburg Mrs. Wanda D. Brown, of Evergreen, Miss Martha J. Durham, and Tracy Ann Durham, both from Lynchburg, and all sisters of the bride, and Miss Donna L Stanley

document.text: The approaching holiday motif was carried out in every detail Saturday evening when Mr. and Mrs. Grover E. Smith were hosts at a dinner party in their home. The guests were Mr. Smiths brother and sisters and their spouses, descendents of the late Mr. and Mrs. E. Holmes Smith. Those enjoying this party were Mr. and Mrs. H. Burnette Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Bobby Reynolds of Lynchburg, and Mr. and Mrs. Lynwood L. Stanley, Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Dutch Jamerson and Mr. and Mrs. E. N. Skeeter Fuller all of Appomattox. This is annual event with the hosts rotating.

There will be at least four flights in the mens tournament and two flights in the ladies tourna ment. There will be prizes in each flight. Qualifying scores, 36 holes for men, and 18 holes for ladies, must be turned in. As set up, the first flight will include .Freddy Mitchell, Frank Jones, Ned Hancock and Janies Paul ette. document.text: Sgt. Lynwood L. Stanley, of the Virginia State Police gave a talk and demonstration on the use of radar in apprehending automobile speeders at a meeting of the Appo mattox County Junior Chamber of Commerce Monday evening. The meeting was held at the cafeteria of Appomattox Garment Co., Inc. President Billy Conner presided at the meeting. It was decided to sponsor an All-Star softball game on Friday night, July 16, at the Town Ball Park. Two teams will be made up of All-Star players from the town softball league. Pitchers and catchers will be from the Lynchburg Class A Softball League. Gerald To rn in and Fred Thomas will pitch. The following new members have been accepted by the club and will be inducted at the next meeting the Rev. Charles Addington, Abbitt Coleman, John W. Crafton, La than Harvey, Millard Harvey and Shearer Robertson.

document.text: Sergeant Leslie L. Stanley, who retired from the State Police force Friday has announced his candidacy for Appomattox Coun ty Sheriff, opposing incumbent Walter Conner in the July 9 Democratic primary. Under Stjte Bailee regulations personnel with a! least ZS Sfears creditable service are retired at age 60. Under this regulation Stanley could have worked until Jan. 1, 1964 but chose to retire early In order to be able to run for sheriff this year. He was born Dec. 11, 1903 at Hebron Church in Appomattox County and attended Appomat tox High School. He previously worked for the Norfolk  West ern Railway and the Virginia Supply Co. of Bluenfield, W. Va. before joining the State Police June 18, 1930. Stanley had served all his time in State Police Area 21, of which

document.text: Quarterly Conference. The second quarterly conference for Appomattox circuit was held ai Mount Comfort church ou Saturday md Sunday last-. Though the vvea- her was unfavorable, there was a large congregation present. Doctor Whitehead being absent in Nasbyilh Teiin., attending a meeting of tin- lenejal Roalds, the Rev. Wallace R. Evans, of Lynchburg, preached, and h pastor, Rev. P. Ai. Bell, presided over the business meetings. A en bountiful dinner was provided by the good people of the church, aim everybody present was invited tu partake of it. Good cheer, harmo ny, and peace prevailed and the conference was one of the most pleasant which this vrier has evei attended. The pastor, presiding, dispatched busin ss with ease and satisfaction and the sermons b Mr. Elans were of a high order, and were greatly enjoyed. We were glad to see you, Mr. Ed itor, together with Captain J . H. Stanley, L. T Seay, and Brother J . R. H ill, present and here extend an invitation to come again. The reports were very encourag ing, and showed the circuit to be in good condi ion. The stewards are active, earnest, and faithful. During the session, the business was suspended to allow fhe commit tee for the new church to wait on ihe congregation for contributions io that work, and the neat sum of 40 was raised in a few minutes. A resolution was passed iustrucl- ing the delegates from this circuit lo the ensuing District Conference to invite that conference to hold its next session 1900 at West Appo mattox, as the guests of the whole circuit. The follovviug delegates and alter nates were elected to the ensuing Distict Conference Delegates Milton Isbell, J . F. Purdimi, and T. Binge Moore alternatesJohn  J .1 Shearer, A. H . Clement, and W. F. Burge. The next session wiil be held at Wesley Chapel. AI.

document.text: District VII Conference of Social Work held its second quarterly meet ing on September 9, in the auditor ium of Piedmont Sanatorium, Burke- ville, Va. Mr. Williams, from the Unemploy ment Compensation Board, discussed eligibility requirements for Unem ployment Compensation. Dr. Scott, Director of Piedmont Sanatorium, discussed recent tuberculosis trends. The highlight of the meeting was a tour of the Sanatorium. The third quarteerly meeting will be held Thursday, December 9, at Farmville. Representatives from Appomattox County at the Burksville meeting were Mrs. Emma Y. Hunter, and Mrs. Flora L. Stanley.

document.text: APPOMATTOX  W i l l i a m Harrison Stanley, 85, of Rt. 1, Appomattox, a retired foreman for the Virginia Highway Depart ment, died unexpectedly today at 7 a.m. at his home. Born in Appomattox County, he was the son of William Burl and Anne Viar Stanley. He was a member of Memorial Metho dist Church in Appomattox. He is survived by seven sons, Clarence H. Stanley, of Lynch burg, William B. Stanley of Madison Heights, and L. L. Stan ley, sheriff of Appomattox Coun ty, Samuel L. Stanley, M. A. Stanley, H. B. Stanley and Ed win T. Stanley, all of Appomat tox frur daughters, Mrs. Kelly Knight and Mrs. Curtis J. Page, both of Lynchbu g and Mrs. G. B. Doss and Mrs. Samuel L. Page, both of Appomattox a sister, Mrs. Mary Crooks, of Lynchburg 30 grandchildren and ! 23 great grandchildren. Funeral services were conduct- ! ed at 11 a.m. Monday at Robert- j son Funeral Home by the Rev. Forrest Wagoner with burial in j Liberty Cemetery. Pallbearers I were Bobby Stanley, Clayton Stanley, Clarence S. Stanley, Jr., Edwin T. Stanley, Robert Kelly Knight and Dicky Wright.

document.text: Two youths who escaped Sun day afternoon from Appomattox County Jail under the pretext of washing the jail windows were  taken into custody early Mon- day, Sheriff L. L. Stanley re- j ported. j The boys, age 18 and 15, from Lynchburg Training School and Hospital, had recently been con !victed of breaking and entering I and each sentenced to five years the sheriff said. A woman employed as a baby sitter for Jailer H. A. White, who lives with his family at the jail, was working Sunday dur ing the absence of the jailer and his wife. Sheriff Stanley said the youths told the woman they were sup posed to wash windows but had nothing to do it with. When the woman brought cleaning items, the boys dashed by her and es caped, Stanley said. The two escapees were picked up early Monday on a second ary road. They had traveled only about three miles from jail.

document.text: Two outstanding speakers, both vitally interested in the promotion of education, will appear on the program of the Appomattox High School P.-T. A. meeting on Tues day, Oct. 25, at 800 P. M., in the school auditorium. Dr. M. Weldon Thompson, pro fessor of Education . and Sociology at Lynchburg College, and JOr!. John G. Potts, a member of the Bedford County School Board, will address the group along the lines that will tie in with the theme for the year, Better School and Community Re lations. Dr. Thompson will be intro duced by H. E. Kerr, principal of the Appomattox Highh School, and T. DeWitt Evans, chairman of the Appomattox School Board, will pre sent Dr. Potts. j Sgt. Jack Couch, president, will i preside over the meeting. Sgt. Couch has announced the ap-. pointment of the following commit tee chairmen, with each chairman to name co-workers program, Mrs. L. L. Stanley hospitality, Mrs. C. S. Martin membership, Mrs. H. E. Kerr publicity, Mrs. H. W. Runkle safety, W. E. Hancock building and grounds, G. E. Smith budget and finance, Mrs. T. DeWitt Evans health, Mrs. R. D. Robinson li brary, Miss Julia I. Asher music, Mrs. H. T. Barger athletic, E. W. Harvey citizenship advisory, Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson. The cafeteria committee named by the president in June and which functioned during the summer, is composed of Miss Laura Motley, chairman Mrs. Ivey Holland, Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley, Mrs. George F. Abbitt, Jr. H. E. Kerr, Miss Julia I. .Asher, Mrs. A. N. Price and Mrs. W. A. Williams. An all-out effort is being made by the publicity and membership committees to create a keen inter est in the P.-T. A. organization this year and to have a record member ship of patrons from every section of the county. Mrs. Stanley, chair man of the program committee, has planned interesting programs for each monthly meeting, all relative to the general theme, Better School and Community Relations. The public is invited to attend any or all of these meetings.

document.text: To The Voters of Appomattox, Va. I am 59 years old and under State Police regulations could have worked until January 1, 1964, but chose to retire early to run for sheriff of our county. If eleoted I will draw no re tirement pay from the State Police as long as I serve as an elected officer. Your vote and support will be gratefully appreciated. L. L. Stanley

document.text: Three young men and a girl, escapees from the Lynchburg Training School, were appre hended near Pamplin about 10 a.m. Tuesday morning by the Appomattox County Sheriffs De partment and State Police. Sheriff L. L. Stanley reported that at least 157 worth of mer chandise had been stolen from the Howard Williams store in Pamplin early Tuesday morning. Almost all of this, plus about 22 in change was recovered from the young escapees. They were turned over to Training School authorities. The stolen merchandise includ ed guns, boxes of ammunition, pocket knives, flashlights, a tran sistor radio and food and cloth ing.

document.text: There are four contests awaiting the decision of the voters. In Stonewall Magisterial District there is a three-way race for the office of supervisor. Incumbent John P. Alvis, Jr., is being opposed by O. W. Martin, Jr., and Hpbert B. Scruggs. Over 800 votes are expect ed at the three precincts in Stone wall District. Veteran incumbent James H. OBrien is being opposed for nomi nation for another-term as Commis sioner of the Revenue by H. H. Caldwell, Jr. - Incumbent David T. Robertson is being opposed for Sheriff by J. Alex Bingham, a retired State Police Lieutenant. Deputy Treasurer John Garland Plunkett and Thomas Terrill Martin, are vieing for the nomination for County Treasurer. These contests have been the oc casion of active campaigns, both by the contestants and their friends. Many letters have been mailed to the voters and personal appeals have kept all hands on the go fonthe past three months. Predictions as to the outcome de pend on which side you question, but the overa-all conclusion is that there will be a heavy vote and that at least some of the contests will be close. Most contestants are preparing their workers for a major effort on1! election day and will try to see that no eligible voter fails to go to the polls. There are ten voting precincts in Appomattox County. Election offi cials, aeording to a list secured by this newspaper yesterday, will be as follows Court House Precinct Judges J. H. Lucado, L J. Mor ris and J. W. Durrum. Clerks Mrs. L. L. Stanley and Mrs. Lou C. Rog ers.

document.text: The Womans Club off Appomat tox will have a dinner meeting on Monday night, March 6 , at the high schookgaffeteria at 630 oclock. Th American Home and Conserv ation Department, of Mrs. F. F, Carraia chairman, will present the program. Mrs. O. E. Zacharias, Jr., of Richmond, will be the speaker. She will be introduced by Mrs. J. W. Flood, vice-president of the Alice Kyle District of the Virginia Fed eration of Womans Clubs. Mrs. Za charias is Legislative Chairman for the Virginia Federation and Chair man of the Virginia Council of Legislative Chairmen. Hostesses for the meeting will be Mrs. L. L. Stanley, Mrs. T. M. Trent, Mrs. David Trent, Mrs. Robert Hub bard, Mis Laura Mottley and Miss Flora Williams.
